user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of data_generator:
```c
static ssize_t
data_generator (void *cls, uint64_t pos, char *buf, size_t max)
{
  (void) cls; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  (void) pos; /* Unused. Silent compiler warning. */
  if (max < 80)
    return 0;
  memset (buf, 'A', max - 1);
  buf[79] = '\n';
  return 80;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
memset (buf, 'A', max - 1);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 21.17 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation provided the function contract holds: the code checks if (max < 80) and only proceeds when max >= 80, so memset(buf, 'A', max - 1) writes bytes 0..(max-2) which is within a buffer of size max. A violation would occur only if the caller supplies an incorrect max (i.e. buf actually has fewer than max bytes) — in that case memset could write beyond the bounds of the object referenced by buf.
